title: How To Tell Your Story: Cornerstone Course I
description: Weaves together the art of writing with the principles of design thinking to explore the transformative power of story in both self-discovery and academic discourse. Covers the multifaceted process of writing, from brainstorming and outlining to drafting, revising, and editing. Emphasizes thesis statements, persuasive arguments, and integration of evidence. Digital tools including AI are embraced throughout.

title: How to Design Your Life: A Journey Through Personal Epistemology
description: Empowers students to become the architect of their own life by critically examining beliefs, values, and assumptions. Covers eight essential life domains: physical health, mental health, spiritual health, relationships, finances, play, growth, and career. Applies design thinking principles. Culminates in a personalized four-year life plan.

title: How to Communicate in a Global Context
description: Delves into the complexities of communication in a globalized world, examining cultural nuances, technological advancements, and cross-cultural communication strategies. Covers public speaking, written communication, visual communication, and debate in varied cultural settings.

title: How to Lead: Transforming Insights from History into Modern Movements
description: Comprehensive exploration of modern leadership theories, contemporary approaches, and timeless lessons from influential leaders. Analyzes case studies and social movements. Final project involves designing a movement and creating a model campaign.

title: How to Use Math in Real Life: The Mathematical Mindsets that Shape Our World
description: Explores mathematics as a flexible, conceptual, and creative way of thinking. Covers quantitative reasoning, linear equations, data analysis, and social justice applications of math. Emphasizes mathematical mindsets, productive struggle, and ethical dimensions of mathematical applications.

title: How Your Brain Works
description: Blends foundational neuroscience with applied psychology. Covers brain structures, cognitive processes (attention, memory, learning agility), habits, and decision-making. Students design and conduct personal experiments to test learning strategies and build better habits.

title: How to "Be Creative" in Partnership with Computation & Machine Learning
description: Explores the evolving relationship between human and computational creativity. Covers cognitive and emotional factors influencing creativity, hands-on experimentation with generative tools and machine learning, and 360-degree feedback on creative products.

title: How to Use Data Science & Game Thinking for Social Impact
description: Navigates the intersection of data science, game theory, and social sciences to tackle societal challenges. Covers systems thinking, data modeling, research methods, and ethical implications. Final project involves creating a framework addressing a critical social challenge.

title: How Can We Thrive? Scientific Inquiry & the Future of Sustainability (Collective Capstone)
description: Examines Earth's sustainability through physical and biological sciences. Applies systems thinking to environmental integrity, economic viability, and social equity. Covers renewable energy, sustainable materials, circular economy, bio-inspired design, climate change, nanotechnology, and sustainable agriculture.

title: How to Design Social Innovation/Impact Solutions to Thrive | SFBU Capstone
description: Guides students through the design thinking process: user research, problem definition, ideation, and prototyping. Offers a social impact entrepreneurship pathway including support to launch an LLC or 501(c)3. Integrates social impact, business administration, and wellness.

title: English Structure and Composition
description: Focuses on structural components of academic writing: parts of speech, sentence types, parallelism, word usage, punctuation, unity, coherence, and structure of paragraphs and standard academic essays.

title: Expository Writing
description: Fundamental college writing course covering mechanics of communication and informative writing. Students enhance skills through prewriting, organizing, drafting, revising, and editing expository essays. Covers grammar, sentence structure, punctuation, and persuasive writing.

title: Critical Thinking
description: Focuses on becoming an effective provider and consumer of ideas. Students learn to identify message intent, judge argument soundness, and evaluate evidence validity. Covers clear, impartial problem-solving and decision-making across speaking, writing, debating, and persuading.

title: Public Speaking
description: Develops effective skills in extemporaneous speaking, formal presentations, and listening. Covers nonverbal communication, cultural differences in communication, and research methodology.

title: Small Group Communication
description: Covers theories and principles of small group decision-making and problem-solving. Provides hands-on experience working in small groups and opportunities to observe real-life task-oriented groups.

title: Intercultural Communication
description: Introduces theories and practices regarding intercultural relationships and communication. Helps students adapt to a diverse workforce. Covers forces that shape cultures and influence intercultural contacts.

title: Modern American Literature
description: Examines fiction and nonfiction by American authors in the 20th and 21st centuries. Covers themes, styles, and genres including drama, action, and science fiction. Requires critical analysis of essays on various readings.

title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to great questions of philosophy using a historical approach. Covers Western and non-Western traditions from pre-Socratic and Confucian times to modern times.

title: Art Appreciation
description: Crash course in Western art aesthetics from ancient art to post-modernism. Provides historical Western art background with comparisons to the East and tools to analyze paintings from one's own cultural point of view.

title: Music Appreciation
description: Explores fundamentals of music through easy-listening examples covering tone, color, harmony, rhythm, mood, dynamics, tempo, themes, and forms. Students analyze music with respect to historical and cultural context.

title: Principles of Ethics
description: Reveals ethical principles and problems applicable to students' lives. Covers application of ethical principles, philosophical background of ethics, ethical practices, and practical ethical problems and solutions.

title: Critical Analysis of Film
description: Examines the impact of film on society and vice versa. Students review, critique, and analyze films. Covers content, meaning, history, and culture of American and foreign films across various genres and film movements.

title: Information Literacy for Academics, Life, and the Workplace
description: Teaches students to read, evaluate, and understand newspapers, magazines, websites, journalistic materials, business writing, and journals. Students learn to evaluate bias, propaganda, agenda, point-of-view, and misinformation.

title: Calculus I
description: First course in calculus series. Covers functions, limits, continuous functions, derivatives and applications, antiderivatives, composite functions and chain rules, graphing techniques, implicit differentiation, finite integrals, and fundamental theorems of calculus.

title: Calculus II
description: Second calculus course covering integration techniques and differentiation of functions of multiple variables. Topics include logarithmic and exponential functions, inverse trigonometric functions, L'Hopital's rule, integration techniques, sequences, series, partial derivatives, and improper integrals.

title: Linear Algebra
description: Covers linear algebra from geometric representation of systems to abstract ideas such as singular value decomposition. Relevant to computer science and data science students. Topics include systems of equations, vector spaces, matrices, and transformations.

title: Probability and Statistics
description: Covers concepts, theory, and applications of probability and statistics. Topics include permutation, combination, random variables, distribution, means and variance, normal distribution, random sampling, estimation, confidence interval, hypothesis testing, linear correlation, and regression.

title: Introduction to Physical Sciences
description: Introductory course exposing students to physical science subjects, including basics of astronomy, chemistry, earth science, and physics.

title: Physics I
description: First course in physics series for engineering students. Topics include vectors, motion, Newton's laws, gravitation, work and energy, momentum, rigid body mechanics, oscillations, kinetic theory of gases, waves and sound, and thermodynamics. Includes weekly lab.

title: Physics Lab I
description: Lab concurrent with PHYS-201. Students learn measuring equipment, experimental procedures, and lab safety. Lab topics include measurements, kinematics, Newton's laws, energy, momentum, conservation laws, collisions, torque, rotational dynamics, waves, and thermodynamics.

title: Physics II
description: Second course in physics series for engineering students. Topics include Coulomb's law, electric fields, DC circuits, magnetic fields, time-varying EM fields, AC circuits, optics, interference, diffraction, and introduction to modern physics. Includes weekly lab.

title: Physics Lab II
description: Lab concurrent with PHYS-202. Covers electrical measuring equipment and experiments in electromagnetism. Topics include electric field, simple circuits, resistors, DC/AC circuits, Kirchhoff's laws, capacitors, magnetic effects, inductors, RLC circuits, geometrical optics, and lenses.

title: California History
description: Exposes students to California's unique history and evolution. Covers social, economic, and political development over the last three centuries, spanning Native American, Spanish, Mexican, and American periods. Uses lectures, case studies, and field trips.

title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Reflects on theories and concepts of behavior and processes of the mind. Covers motivation, emotion, personality, social behavior, perception, learning, and development. Examines cognitive, forensic, social, and developmental psychology.

title: Cyberpsychology: Understanding Human Behavior in the Digital Age
description: Explores how digital technologies shape human behavior, identity, relationships, mental health, and society. Covers social media, cyberbullying, digital addiction, AI, VR, UX, and algorithmic bias. Culminates in a final design promoting digital well-being or equity.

title: Introduction to Sociology
description: Study of culture, social organization, and social relations. Covers major social problems, their interrelations, and society's role in creating and perpetuating them. Addresses cross-culture and diversity issues.

title: Multiculturalism in the United States
description: Looks into various aspects of multiculturalism in American society, exploring issues related to race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, disability, and other social group identities.

title: Public Administration
description: Introduction to public administration. Covers early key thinkers, public policy formation, public management, human resources, reinvention, privatization, e-government, public finance, performance measurement, and ethics.

title: Civilization and Urbanization
description: Covers the 5,000-year shift from rural to urban worldwide. Topics include ancient walled cities, utopian writings, urban theories, English Garden Cities, American Greenbelt Towns, New Urbanism, Smart Growth, and Healthy Cities.

title: The American Experience
description: Guides students in examining the 20th-century rise of the United States as a modern multiethnic society with emphasis on the socioeconomic and political forces that shaped its development.

title: Modern American History
description: Covers U.S. development from post-Civil War (1865) to the present. Topics include Reconstruction, immigration, industrialization, WWI, Great Depression, New Deal, WWII, Korean War, Vietnam War, civil rights movement, globalization, September 11, terrorism, and modern technology.

title: Early American History
description: Examines early periods of American history including America before Columbus, European expansion, the founding era and Revolution, the Constitution and the New Republic, and subsequent periods up to the Civil War.

title: Emotional Intelligence
description: Covers emotional intelligence (EQ): recognizing one's own emotions and those of others and controlling them. Students learn to manage interpersonal relations and increase EQ by developing abilities to perceive, use, understand, and manage emotions. Includes EQ self-assessment at start and end of term.

title: Professional and Technical Writing
description: Practical instructions about communicating in academic and workplace environments. Students learn to produce technical reports, white papers, proposals, and theses. Covers writing styles, approaches, formats, and citations.

title: Computer Organization
description: Covers fundamental issues in designing and implementing modern computer systems. Topics include RISC vs. CISC CPU design, instruction sets, pipelining, instruction scheduling, cache, storage hierarchy, and modern I/O architectures (PCI, SATA, SCSI, USB).

title: Fundamentals of Embedded Engineering
description: First course in embedded systems series. Topics include microprocessors, memory, registers, I/O, interrupt handling, real-time programming, multitasking, concurrency, mutual exclusion, RTOS overview, and debug issues. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Embedded Engineering Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CE-450. Students gain hands-on experience with embedded systems programming and design. Guided to work on projects involving control systems.

title: Discrete Logic
description: Introduces the Linux operating system and environment. Covers core Linux concepts, shell commands, visual editor, file manipulation and security, utility commands, shell features, regular expressions with grep/sed/awk, basic shell programming, and various Linux shells.

title: Linux & Shell Scripting
description: Familiarizes students with the Linux environment. Topics include Linux OS concepts, shell commands, file manipulation, utility commands, regular expressions, grep/sed/awk, shell programming, file systems, and resource management. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Linux & Shell Scripting Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-230. Hands-on experience with Unix/Linux commands, vi editor, Linux utility, shell scripting/programming, security issues, managing long files, and user environment customization.

title: Introduction to Programming
description: Introduction to computer science using Python. Covers defining and analyzing problems, algorithms, implementation, debugging, documentation, basic algorithms, programming concepts, data types, control structures, iteration, methods, argument passing, and classes.

title: Introduction to Programming Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-250. Covers Python basics: strings, math operations, sequences, user input/output, flow control, file I/O, functions, and exception handling.

title: Data Structures
description: Teaches efficient use of data structures and algorithms. Topics include arrays, stacks, queues, trees, graphs, sorting, hashing, and heap structures. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Data Structures Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-350. Further investigates C language. Topics include pointer structure, structure and union, stack, queue, linked list, sort, binary tree, and heaps.

title: Programming in C and C++
description: Develops skills in designing, coding, and documenting programs in C and C++. Covers data types, expressions, functions, run-time memory allocation, function overloading, template functions, class mechanisms, inheritance, and transitioning from C to C++.

title: Programming in C and C++ Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-360. Practice and development of programming skills in both C and C++.

title: Operating Systems
description: Covers fundamental concepts and implementation techniques of modern operating systems. Topics include processes, threads, concurrency, memory management, file systems, I/O systems, security, and OS virtualization. Case studies on Linux/UNIX, Windows, Android, and VMWare.

title: Compiler Design
description: Provides fundamental knowledge of compilers and interpreters for modern computer languages. Topics include regular expressions, lexical analysis, parsing techniques, context-free grammar, and syntax-directed translation. Hands-on exercises and projects required.

title: Algorithms & Structured Programming
description: Introduces design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms. Covers common algorithms, algorithmic complexity, and data structures. Concentrates on design of algorithms and analysis of their efficiency.

title: Data Modeling and Implementation Techniques
description: First course in relational database series. Topics include database architecture, relational model, SQL, DML, DDL, database design, ER modeling, normalization, denormalization, and physical database design. Uses Oracle and Microsoft SQL Server.

title: Database Technologies Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-457. Hands-on experience in database applications using Oracle and Microsoft SQL servers. Guided work on database design projects.

title: Network Engineering and Management
description: Introduces network communications. Topics include network-layered models (OSI, TCP/IP), architecture, principles, service models and protocols, data communication basics, switching, routing, security, network management, and wireless/mobile networks.

title: Ethical Hacking and Penetration Testing
description: Covers computer hacking techniques in depth. Students learn to quantitatively assess threats to information assets, discover vulnerabilities, and deploy proactive countermeasures. Teaches ethical hacking methods used in professional security roles.

title: Blockchain Technology and Applications
description: Explores fundamentals and applications of blockchain technology. Covers types of blockchain, cryptocurrency underpinnings, real-life cases, and potential disruptive impact on business and society.

title: Java and Internet Applications
description: Introduces Java programming with emphasis on object-oriented concepts, GUI design, and core Java libraries. Covers syntax, classes, inheritance, interfaces, graphics programming, event handling, Swing UI, Java applets, exception handling, and streams.

title: Java Programming Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-480. Weekly hands-on exercises corresponding to lecture material to develop Java programming skills.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning and Data Science
description: Interdisciplinary course combining mathematics, statistics, and programming. Covers gaining knowledge from structured and unstructured data, scientific methods, algorithms, and systems for data science problems.

title: Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence
description: Covers AI applications in problem-solving, reasoning, planning, NLP, computer vision, autonomous navigation, and machine learning. Major algorithms include machine learning, search, Markov decision processes, constraint satisfaction, graphical models, and logic. Uses Python.

title: Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning Lab
description: Lab using Google Colab with numpy, pandas, matplotlib, scikit-learn, seaborn, tensorflow, and Keras. Students implement ML algorithms, build hands-on design projects, and perform data process analysis and error analysis.

title: JavaScript and Internet Programming
description: Advanced programming for Internet application development. Covers client-side and server-side scripting with HTML, JavaScript, CSS, jQuery, Bootstrap, Node.js Express, RESTful API, MongoDB, Angular, and React. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Object-Oriented Design and Implementations
description: Teaches object-oriented design methodology for algorithm development. Covers problem specification, analysis, data abstraction, encapsulation, aggregation, inheritance, and basic design patterns. Hands-on practice using Python.

title: Senior Capstone Project I
description: First part of senior capstone project. Develops creativity through design effort and implementation of a self-selected project. Steps include research, problem statement formulation, design specifications, alternative solutions, development plan, implementation, and final report.

title: Senior Capstone Project II
description: Second part of the senior capstone series. Students enhance or expand their CS-494 project. Culminates in an open-forum presentation and professional report.

title: Curricular Practicum (Part-Time)
description: Supervised practical experience applying previously studied theory. Part-time practicum (up to 20 hours/week). Must be in good standing, have completed at least two semesters of coursework, and have a written agreement with the practicum site.

title: Curricular Practicum (Full-Time)
description: Supervised practical experience applying previously studied theory. Full-time practicum (20-40 hours/week). Must be in good standing, have completed at least two semesters of coursework, and have a written agreement with the practicum site.

title: Career Development
description: Prepares students to become working professionals. Topics include effective communication strategies, emotional intelligence, diversity and cultural awareness, professional behavior, and interview skills.

title: Fundamentals of Embedded Engineering (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level version of CE-450. First in embedded systems series. Topics include microprocessors, memory, I/O, interrupt handling, real-time programming, multitasking, concurrency, RTOS overview, and debug issues. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Embedded Engineering Lab (Graduate)
description: Graduate lab concurrent with CE-450G. Hands-on experience with embedded systems programming, design, and control systems projects.

title: Real-Time Systems and Programming
description: Second in embedded systems series. Covers real-time OS programming, real-time specification and design, real-time kernels, memory management, task management, synchronization, inter-task communication, and queuing models. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Embedded Design in Networking Environment
description: Covers protocol stack implementation/porting in RTOS. Topics include embedded real-time system architecture, multitasking, task scheduling, synchronization, semaphores, and message queues. Uses industry-standard RTOS.

title: Embedded Design in Device Driver Environment
description: Investigates OS components interacting with device drivers. Topics include OS architecture, I/O API, kernel internals, building/loading/debugging drivers, device driver architecture, I/O request processing, plug-and-play, memory management, and DMA.

title: Embedded Software Design in Linux
description: Prepares students for embedded Linux development. Topics include Linux kernel initialization, Linux drivers, bootloaders (U-Boot), embedded Linux file systems, Memory Technology Devices, debugging tools (gdb, KGDB), cross-development environments, and BusyBox configuration.

title: Compiler Design (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level compiler design. Covers modern computer languages, regular expressions, lexical analysis, parsing techniques, context-free grammar, and syntax-directed translation. Hands-on exercises and semester projects required.

title: Algorithms & Structured Programming (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level algorithms course. Covers design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms, algorithmic complexity, and data structures for engineering problems.

title: Data Modeling and Implementation Techniques (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level relational database course. Topics include database architecture, relational models, SQL, DML, DDL, ER modeling, normalization, and physical database design. Uses Oracle and Microsoft SQL Server.

title: Database Technologies Lab (Graduate)
description: Graduate lab concurrent with CS-457G. Hands-on experience in database applications using Oracle and Microsoft SQL servers and database design projects.

title: Network Engineering and Management (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level network communications course. Topics include OSI/TCP/IP models, architecture, protocols, data communication, switching, routing, security, network management, and wireless/mobile networks.

title: Ethical Hacking and Penetration Testing (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level ethical hacking. Covers computer hacking techniques in depth, threat assessment, vulnerability discovery, and proactive countermeasures deployment.

title: Blockchain Technology and Applications (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level blockchain course. Explores fundamentals, types of blockchain, real-life cases, and potential business and societal impact of blockchain technology.

title: Java and Internet Applications (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level Java course. Covers Java language basics, OOP, GUI design, graphics programming, event handling, Swing, Java applets, exception handling, streams, and files.

title: Java Programming Lab (Graduate)
description: Graduate lab concurrent with CS-480G. Weekly hands-on Java programming exercises.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning and Data Science (Graduate)
description: Graduate data science course. Covers gaining knowledge from structured and unstructured data, scientific methods, algorithms, and systems for data science problems.

title: Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence (Graduate)
description: Graduate AI course. Covers AI applications including NLP, computer vision, autonomous navigation, machine learning, and business intelligence. Major algorithms include search, Markov decision processes, constraint satisfaction, and logic. Uses Python.

title: Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning Lab (Graduate)
description: Graduate lab using Google Colab with numpy, pandas, matplotlib, scikit-learn, seaborn, tensorflow, and Keras. Students implement ML algorithms and build hands-on design projects.

title: JavaScript and Internet Programming (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level Internet programming. Covers HTML, JavaScript, CSS, jQuery, Bootstrap, Node.js Express, RESTful API, MongoDB, Angular, and React. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Object-Oriented Design in Python
description: Teaches OO design methodology for software development. Covers OO design and analysis, design patterns (Abstract Factory, Observer, Command, Decorator, Adaptor, Iterator, State), and Python language features. Hands-on practice required.

title: Object-Oriented Design in Python Lab
description: Lab concurrent with CS-500. Practice object-oriented design and Python programming skills.

title: Practical Application of Algorithms
description: Expands knowledge of algorithms through practical application to real-world computational problems. Trains students in 'Algorithmic Thinking' to develop conceptual understanding and efficient problem-solving skills for interviews and the workplace.

title: Advanced UNIX/Linux Programming
description: Covers programming in the UNIX/Linux environment using C with system calls. Topics include UNIX file system, process control, signals, and inter-process communications. Requires a term project with substantial programming.

title: UNIX/Linux Network Programming
description: Hands-on UNIX/Linux network programming. Covers Sockets, XTI, RPC, transport layer (TCP/UDP), threads, and client-server design. Hands-on exercises and projects required.

title: Software Project Management
description: Applies current software development approaches to managing complex projects. Topics include software development process, project planning, requirements definition, design specification, usability engineering, verification and validation, and process quality improvement.

title: Software Quality Assurance and Test Automation
description: Teaches static and dynamic techniques for engineering high-quality software. Covers quality management, test development, agile principles, quality risk analysis, system/integration/performance/automated testing, and test automation tools.

title: Advanced Web Programming
description: Teaches how to build modern web applications with web frameworks. Covers HTML, CSS, JavaScript, ORM, MVC architectural pattern, and mobile web development.

title: Python Applications Programming
description: Introduces fundamental and advanced Python features for application development. Covers syntax, variable types, control flows, OOP, regular expressions, multithreading, CGI programming, database access, networking, XML processing, and GUI programming.

title: Advanced Internet Programming and Design
description: In-depth Java programming focusing on advanced features: XML, JNI, threading, network programming, generic programming, and internationalization. Students build enterprise-wide Java solutions for client/server problems.

title: Network Security Fundamentals
description: Covers security issues on the Internet and web. Topics include Internet infrastructure security, techniques to reduce security risks, encryption and cryptography, SSL, web server security, and Java security.

title: Advanced Database Administration
description: In-depth understanding of Oracle DBMS. Topics include Oracle database architecture, configuration and administration, logical/physical database layout, storage management, security, database utilities, monitoring, partitions, and backup/recovery.

title: Advanced Database Design and Analysis
description: Further explores database server development and tuning. Covers stored procedures, functions, packages, database triggers, performance tuning, query optimizers, database hints, and various database access methods.

title: Web Services Techniques and REST Technologies
description: Covers 3-tier enterprise application development. Topics include Spring Framework, JDBC, JPA (Java Persistence API), Hibernate, Spring MVC, Java Servlets, and JavaBeans. Emphasizes best-practice development with ORM tools.

title: Machine Learning and Business Intelligence
description: Introduces methods for using stored business data to make decisions. Covers operational/nonoperational/metadata data types, patterns and associations, data warehouse concepts, and data mining techniques. Uses modern data analysis software.

title: Mobile Computing for Android Mobile Devices
description: Hands-on course developing Android applications including map-based, camera-based, and SMS apps. Covers Android platform, advanced topics including security, IPC, and graphics/UI techniques.

title: Mobile Applications on iPhone Platform
description: In-depth study of design, development, and publication of object-oriented iOS applications using Apple SDK. Students learn to use Xcode, SwiftUI, and UIKit to create iOS apps.

title: Advanced Network Management
description: In-depth understanding of network systems management. Covers SNMP management, MIB, management tools, RMON, RMON2, SNMP2, SNMP3, and ITU TMN architecture. Uses industry applications and computer-based training software.

title: Big Data Processing & Analytics
description: Covers big data computing systems including MapReduce, Hadoop, and Apache Spark. Topics include PageRank, machine learning applications, and social network graph mining.

title: Cloud Computing Infrastructure
description: Introduction to cloud computing infrastructure including cloud frameworks, design patterns, virtualization, Docker, and Kubernetes. Covers scalable and resilient application development in cloud-native environments.

title: Blockchain Development
description: Introduces blockchain fundamentals for decentralized application development. Covers distributed ledgers, consensus mechanisms, smart contracts, and decentralized architecture. Hands-on design, implementation, and deployment of dApps.

title: Network Analysis and Testing
description: Covers computer network analysis and testing techniques. Topics include wiring and cable testing, transmission encoding, MAC addressing, broadcast traffic, switches, Ethernet, Token Ring, IP routing, protocol analysis, and latency. Hands-on exercises with a protocol analyzer.

title: Cloud Security
description: Covers cloud infrastructure security including compute, storage, containers, serverless, IAM, and asset management. Examines multi-cloud and hybrid-cloud security challenges, and cybersecurity principles (Least Privilege, Defense in Depth, Shared Responsibility).

title: Special Topics
description: Special topics courses exposing graduate students to emerging technologies in computer science. Conducted the same way as regular courses by faculty or guest speakers.

title: Computer Science Capstone Course
description: Integrates knowledge and hands-on experience from foundation, core, and elective coursework. Instructor determines course objectives based on CS curriculum and technology trends. Student must take near the end of their program.

title: Curricular Practicum (Graduate Part-Time)
description: Supervised practical training for graduate students. Part-time (up to 20 hours/week). Applies previously studied theory in professional settings.

title: Curricular Practicum (Graduate Full-Time)
description: Supervised practical training for graduate students. Full-time (20-40 hours/week). Applies previously studied theory in professional settings.

title: Mathematics and Statistics for Data Science
description: Provides a solid foundation in mathematical and statistical concepts for data science. Equips students with quantitative skills to analyze and interpret data, make informed decisions, and derive insights from complex datasets.

title: Python Programming for Data Science
description: Foundation course mastering Python programming skills for data analysis and manipulation. Hands-on coding exercises and projects to develop skills for data science challenges.

title: Data Engineering
description: Comprehensive coverage of data engineering principles, techniques, and tools. Topics include data storage, data processing and integration, data warehousing, data security, and scalability/performance optimization.

title: Deep Learning
description: Covers core concepts, techniques, and applications of deep learning. Topics include neural networks (CNNs and RNNs), generative models, and applications in computer vision, NLP, and speech recognition.

title: Natural Language Processing (NLP)
description: Covers fundamental concepts, methods, and applications of NLP. Topics include tokenization, syntactic and semantic analysis, named entity recognition, POS tagging, text classification, machine translation, sentiment analysis, and language models including n-grams, HMMs, and RNNs.

title: Generative AI-Driven Intelligent Apps Development
description: Develops expertise to build intelligent applications using generative AI. Topics include generative AI, deep learning, ML techniques, implementing generative models, ethical considerations, and deploying AI-driven apps. Hands-on projects with real-world case studies.

title: Special Topics (Data Science)
description: Special topics courses exposing graduate students to emerging technologies in data science. Conducted the same way as regular courses by faculty or guest speakers.

title: Data Science Capstone Course
description: Integrates knowledge and hands-on experience from foundation, core, and elective coursework. Instructor determines objectives based on data science curriculum and technology trends. Student must take near the end of their program.

title: Digital Design and HDL
description: Develops ability to design building blocks of modern digital systems. Topics include Verilog HDL, logic modeling, state machine design, memory modeling, FPGA architecture, and EDA tools (Synopsys VCS, Mentor Modelsim, Cadence NC Verilog).

title: Digital Design and HDL Lab
description: Lab concurrent with EE-461G. Hands-on experience with Verilog simulation tools, logic design projects, and scripting languages (Perl, Python, Unix/Linux Shell).

title: Microelectronics Circuit Design and Analysis
description: In-depth understanding of electronic circuit design at the transistor level. Topics include differential amplifiers, current source circuits, amplifier frequency response, feedback, operational amplifiers, and logic circuits. Uses industry-standard CAD tools.

title: Computer Architecture
description: Introduces organization, design, and applications of modern computer architecture. Topics include performance benchmarks, instruction sets (RISC and CISC), memory, parallelism, I/O, multicore processors, and GPU. Includes HDL and SPIM simulations.

title: Advanced Computer Architecture
description: Further investigates modern computer design. Topics include multiprocessor architecture, interconnection networks, pipelines, data flow, algorithm structures, memory and cache design. Hands-on project required.

title: Advanced Digital IC Design
description: Advanced digital circuit design in CMOS technologies. Covers combinational/sequential logic design, arithmetic building blocks, memory circuits, scaling, process variation, signal integrity, and power consumption. Uses HSPICE, Virtuoso, and Composer.

title: VLSI Design - Place and Route
description: Third in the VLSI design series. Introduces ASIC place and route. Topics include design flow, floor planning, power planning, timing-driven placement, static time analysis (STA), special routing, final routing, ECO, and batch mode jobs.

title: Mobile and Wireless Communication
description: Covers frequency reuse, wireless channel characteristics, modulation/demodulation, equalization, channel coding, speech coding, multiple access techniques (FDMA, TDMA, CDMA), and commercial standards (AMPS, GSM, IS136, IS-95). Uses MATLAB or System View simulations.

title: Advanced Analog IC Design
description: Covers concepts and techniques in analog IC design including device modeling, basic circuit building blocks, feedback systems, frequency response, and noise. EDA tools used in assignments and projects.

title: Application Specific Integrated Circuit Design (ASIC)
description: HDL-based ASIC design. Topics include ASIC/CPLD/FPGA library modeling, cell characterization, static timing analysis, place and route, DFT, fault modeling, and EDA tools (Synopsys, Cadence, Mentor).

title: Introduction to the Internet of Things (IoT)
description: Addresses IoT concepts and architecture, IoT enablers, data and knowledge management, and IoT security and reliability. Students complete a term project demonstrating IoT for a chosen application using an embedded system or development platform.

title: Advanced FPGA Design and Implementations
description: Digital design using Xilinx FPGAs. Covers FPGA architecture, combinational and sequential logic, finite state machines, RAM, DSP blocks. Hands-on exercises required.

title: System on Chip (SoC) Design
description: Covers SoC components including processor, memory, digital IPs, analog/mixed-signal modules, RF, and interfaces. Focuses on ARM-based on-chip bus platforms, digital IP verification, and SoC integration trends.

title: Design Verification with System Verilog
description: Covers SoC design verification methodologies. Topics include verification strategies, IP block verification, ASIC verification, building verification platforms, test coverage, PLI routines, and formal verification.

title: Special Topics (Electrical Engineering)
description: Special topics courses exposing graduate students to emerging technologies in electrical engineering. Conducted the same way as regular courses by faculty or guest speakers.

title: Electrical Engineering Capstone Course
description: Integrates knowledge and hands-on experience from foundation, core, and elective coursework. Instructor determines course objectives based on EE curriculum and technology trends. Student must take near the end of their program.

title: Career Development (Graduate)
description: Prepares graduate students to become working professionals. Topics include effective communication strategies, emotional intelligence, diversity and cultural awareness, professional behavior, and interview skills.

title: Financial Accounting
description: Study of accounting as an information system. Covers accounting information system, recording and reporting of business transactions, GAAP, financial statements, statement analysis, assets/liability/equity valuation, revenue and expense recognition, and cash flow.

title: Managerial Accounting
description: Studies how managers use accounting information for decision-making, planning, and controlling. Covers cost terms, cost behavior, cost structure, cost-volume-profit analysis, cost systems, and performance analysis.

title: Cost Accounting
description: Applies financial accounting essentials to management practice. Covers cost definitions, cost behavior, cost estimation, cost accounting in manufacturing/service, planning and control, capital budgeting, and financial statement analysis.

title: Intermediate Accounting I
description: Enhances understanding of accounting principles for aspiring accounting professionals. Topics include financial accounting standards, financial statement preparation, required disclosures, current assets, revenue recognition, and fixed assets.

title: Intermediate Accounting II
description: Continuation of Intermediate Accounting I. Covers current and long-term liabilities, stockholders' equity, investments, pension and postretirement benefits, leases, and cash flow statements.

title: Introduction to Taxation
description: Covers taxation concepts applied to individual income, deductions, credits, property transactions, and tax accounting methods. Prepares students to prepare individual income tax returns professionally. Also covers taxation rules for financial planning.

title: SQL and Relational Databases
description: Emphasizes SQL/RDBMS as a tool for business and data analytics. Covers relational database theory, best practices, SQL for entering/retrieving/updating/sorting data, calculating statistics, and modifying data storage structures.

title: Excel for Finance, Accounting & Analytics
description: Mastery of Excel for professional use. Covers graphics, conditional formatting, sorting, pivot tables, conditional calculations, data loading, and Excel's powerful functions and Analysis Tool Pak/Solver extensions.

title: Introduction to Business Analytics
description: Teaches basics of business analytics. Students use popular data analysis tools to analyze business data for understanding trends, making forecasts, and improving decision-making and business strategies.

title: Data Visualization
description: Teaches how to explore data and provide insight using data visualization techniques. Students design, develop, analyze, and interpret various visualizations and develop compelling presentations based on case studies.

title: Intro to Machine Learning-Based Forecasting
description: Hands-on application of machine learning to business prediction, forecasting, and decision-making. Python-based, covering AR/ARIMA and AI-based forecasting methods. Covers model selection, data preparation, training, optimization, and recommendations.

title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI)
description: Comprehensive introduction to AI covering history, fundamental concepts, applications, risks, and mitigation strategies. Covers AI components, technologies, development processes, and ethical considerations.

title: Introduction to Business Law
description: Introductory-level U.S. business law. Covers the U.S. legal system, sources of law, ethics, contracts, torts, agency, criminal law, business organizations, and judicial and administrative processes.

title: Independent Research Project
description: One-on-one faculty mentorship for in-depth research in a business topic of the student's choice. Culminates in a publication-quality research paper suitable for peer-reviewed journal submission.

title: Senior Project
description: Culminating undergraduate experience demonstrating mastery of specialized knowledge in a student's professional area of interest. Students communicate results in writing and oral presentations. Projects may be used for industry or graduate study portfolios.

title: Principles of Macroeconomics
description: Introductory aggregate economic analysis. Topics include aggregate measures, macroeconomic equilibrium, money and financial institutions, monetary and fiscal policy, international economics, and economic growth.

title: Principles of Microeconomics
description: Introductory course on individual economic decision-making. Topics include scarcity, specialization, market equilibrium, elasticity, production and cost theory, market structures, factor markets, and market failure.

title: Managerial Economics
description: Rigorous study of microeconomics and macroeconomics with business applications. Covers consumption models, market efficiency, behavioral economics, game theory, macro-financial linkages, monetary policy, and econometric skills.

title: Fundamentals of Finance
description: Introduces finance and financial management. Covers financial statements, cash flow analysis, time value of money, bond and stock valuation, risk and return, capital budgeting, and international finance.

title: Principles of Management
description: Covers basic skills, applications, and foundations of management. Includes organizational structure, planning, organizing, leadership, motivation, decision-making, communication, and negotiation.

title: Organizational Behavior and Management
description: Explores dimensions of organizational behavior including communication, self-awareness, perception, motivation, problem-solving, and culture. Covers leadership theories and organizational change.

title: Project Management
description: Introduces project and program management principles, roles of project management, matrix organization, and project management techniques for efficient execution and completion. Requires proposal development, case studies, and independent projects.

title: Production and Operations Management
description: Balances theory and practice of production and operations management. Covers strategies, process design, and quantitative techniques. Uses Excel Analysis Tool Pak and Solver for multivariate operational constraints.

title: Entrepreneurship
description: Explores the full range of entrepreneurial processes including evaluation, development, and creation of a successful business. Covers organizational structure, market analysis, financing entrepreneurial ventures, and business plan development.

title: Launching Innovative Startups
description: Hands-on project-based course covering the entrepreneur development process from ideation and business modeling through funding and marketing launch. Topics include design thinking, lean startup, market validation, and startup management.

title: Business Innovation  A Historical and Cultural Perspective
description: Explores business innovation through history, culture, and global influence from the Industrial Revolution to the digital age. Covers the role of entrepreneurship, cross-cultural problem-solving, and the interplay between tradition and disruption.

title: Agility-Based Leadership
description: Uses Business Agility Institute best practices to cultivate adaptive organizations through cultural engagement, agile principles, and operational efficiency. Covers workforce engagement strategies, performance-driven business models, and continuous improvement.

title: HTML & CSS Web Page Construction
description: Provides understanding of how websites work and proficiency in HTML and CSS to create, modify, and maintain web pages. Covers Hypertext Markup Language, Cascading Style Sheets, and optionally JavaScript and SQL.

title: Principles of Marketing
description: Introduces major marketing principles, marketing's role in companies and the global economy. Covers market segmentation, product planning, new product development, wholesalers/retailers, pricing, and promotion.

title: Marketing Management
description: Studies marketing management via real-world case analysis. Covers situation assessment, strategy formulation, marketing planning, implementation, and evaluation.

title: Monetizing Intellectual Property
description: Covers innovative models and strategies for generating capital from intangible assets. Topics include outright sales, third-party licensing, royalty securitizations, Bowie Bonds, collateralization, copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets, and patents.

title: The Art of Negotiation
description: Develops advanced skills for complex negotiation scenarios. Covers theories and strategies for win-win outcomes, strategic mindset, disciplined preparation, and interpersonal skills. Includes Silicon Valley case studies and simulations.

title: Cost Accounting (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level cost accounting. Applies financial accounting essentials to management, covering cost definitions, behavior, estimation, and application to manufacturing/service organizations, planning, control, capital budgeting, and financial statement analysis.

title: Intermediate Accounting I (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level intermediate accounting. Covers accounting standards, financial statement preparation, required disclosures, current assets, revenue recognition, and fixed assets.

title: Intermediate Accounting I Lab (Graduate)
description: Lab concurrent with ACC-451G. Students work with real-world accounting situations including multiyear accrual recognition and in-depth study of current assets using accounting software.

title: Intermediate Accounting II (Graduate)
description: Graduate continuation of Intermediate Accounting I. Covers liabilities, stockholders' equity, investments, pension and postretirement benefits, leases, and cash flow statements.

title: Introduction to Taxation (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level individual taxation. Covers taxation concepts for income, deductions, credits, property transactions, and tax accounting methods. Covers taxation rules for financial planning.

title: Advanced Accounting
description: For accounting graduate students. Covers consolidation requirements, consolidated financial statements, and accounting techniques for various business and non-business entities. Includes tax aspects and case studies.

title: Federal Taxation of Business Enterprises
description: Covers federal taxation of corporations, partnerships, estates, and trusts. Enables students to prepare corporation and partnership tax returns professionally. Also covers rules governing trusts and estates.

title: Auditing
description: Covers auditing techniques, procedures, practices, and programs based on GAAP. Students learn best practices for working document preparation and report writing.

title: AI in Modern-Day Society: A Survey
description: Explores the intersection of AI and emerging technologies including Web 3.0, Metaverse, Blockchain, Cybersecurity, Quantum, Biotechnology, IoT, Edge Computing, Space technologies, and ESG frameworks. Also covers Physical AI and Agentic AI.

title: Management and Leadership in AI
description: Covers leadership in AI-driven organizations. Topics include leading AI-human teams, organizational transformation, HR strategy, AI-powered innovation, AI ethics, governance, and cross-industry AI applications.

title: Corporate Strategy in AI
description: Equips business leaders with strategic frameworks and governance principles for enterprise AI integration. Topics include AI value creation, portfolio and platform strategies, ethical/legal risk assessment, talent and data infrastructure, and AI KPIs. Includes capstone consulting project.

title: Data Science and AI
description: Comprehensive foundation in data science and AI. Covers data preprocessing, statistical analysis, machine learning, deep learning, and AI model development using Python, R, and cloud-based platforms. Emphasizes ethical AI.

title: Leveraging AI and Emerging Technologies for Startups
description: Explores how startups can use AI and emerging technologies for innovative, scalable business models. Topics include AI-driven product development, cloud infrastructure, blockchain, IoT, automation, and lean startup principles. Final project: tech-enabled startup pitch.

title: Server-Side Data Processing Using Python/PHP
description: Teaches implementation of industrial-scale business algorithms and processing of complex data sets with backend analytics and relational database engines using Python or PHP server-side scripting.

title: Introduction to Business Analytics (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level business analytics. Uses Microsoft Excel tools for business data analysis, trend understanding, forecasting, and decision-making. Includes probability theory, hypothesis testing, and predictive modeling.

title: Data Visualization (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level data visualization. Students design, develop, analyze, and interpret visualizations and develop compelling data-driven presentations based on case studies.

title: Intro to Machine Learning-Based Forecasting (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level ML forecasting. Python-based, covering AR/ARIMA and AI-based methods. Covers model selection, data preparation, anomaly handling, training, optimization, and decision-maker recommendations.

title: Quantitative Methods for Business
description: Introduces contemporary business decision-making methodologies. Covers quantitative analysis, management science, Monte Carlo simulations, stochastic forecasting, portfolio optimization, dynamic project management, and VBA coding. Uses Excel, SPSS, Minitab, R, and other tools.

title: Business Analytics for Dashboards
description: Teaches how to design and build analytics dashboards and data visualizations using a leading analytics tool. Covers best practices for data visualization and dashboard design.

title: Intermediate Business Analytics
description: Teaches business analytics as applied by enterprises for strategy and decision-making. Covers foundations of business analytics, data analysis tools, major models, and big data/big analytics trends. Hands-on exercises required.

title: Process Management for Analytics
description: Teaches how to design and implement a self-service analytics (SSA) business process pipeline. Students learn to make trade-offs among computer technologies and apply their SSA pipeline to solve enterprise-level business challenges.

title: Special Topics: Quantitative Risk Management (CQRM)
description: Covers data and decision analytics under risk and uncertainty. Topics include Monte Carlo simulations, financial forecasting, predictive analytics, decision analytics, strategic real options, and capital portfolio allocation. Qualifies students to take the CQRM certification exam.

title: Professional and Technical Writing (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level professional and technical writing. Covers technical reports, white papers, proposals, theses, and resumes. Also covers writing styles, approaches, formats, and citations.

title: Independent Research Project (Graduate)
description: Graduate one-on-one faculty mentorship for in-depth graduate-level research in business. Culminates in a publication-quality paper suitable for peer-reviewed journal submission.

title: Special Topics (Business)
description: Special topics courses exposing graduate students to emerging business topics. Conducted the same way as regular courses by faculty or guest speakers.

title: Business Capstone Course
description: Integrates knowledge and hands-on experience from foundation, core, and elective coursework in the MBA or MSBAn program. Instructor guides students to develop integration ability. Student must take near the end of the program.
prerequisites: 24 credit hours in related graduate business program

title: The Economics of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets
description: Fresh perspective on financial and monetary policies. Topics include interest rate behavior, monetary strategy, demand for money, and insight into monetary policy, financial system regulation, and internationalization of financial markets.

title: Financial Management
description: Introduces modern financial theories, tools, and methods for corporate financial management. Focuses on analysis and forecast of internal operations, short-term and long-term capital use, and maximizing shareholders' equity.

title: Investment Analysis
description: Covers foundations of investment management including portfolio theory, market efficiency, asset pricing models, factor models, and option pricing theory. Students create optimal investment strategies.

title: Financial Risk Management
description: Further introduces modern financial theories for dealing with financial risks. Covers financial risk management for corporations, financial institutions, and government enterprises.

title: International Trade and Investment
description: Covers theories of international trade, comparative advantage, regional economic blocks, multilateral trading system, and trade barriers. Students learn international payment, shipping, and distribution mechanics.

title: Corporate Finance
description: Covers executive compensation, corporate governance, and bankruptcy law. Also covers mergers, acquisitions, and valuations; corporate restructuring; LBOs; MBOs; and merchant banking.

title: Portfolio Management
description: Teaches advanced portfolio decision-making. Topics include index models, portfolio performance measures, bond portfolio management, interest immunization, stock market anomalies, and market efficiency.

title: International Finance
description: Prepares students for careers in international finance. Covers the financial environment of multinational firms, foreign exchange management, and financial management in global markets.

title: Green and Socially Responsible Management
description: Covers environmental and social responsibility demands on modern businesses. Students learn to utilize socially responsible methodologies and formulate enterprise-wide policies integrating sustainability values.

title: Human Resource Management
description: Comprehensive overview of personnel management. Covers job analysis, candidate screening, interviewing, testing, hiring, evaluating, training, motivating, promoting, and compensation. Also covers global HR, diversity awareness, and sexual harassment requirements.

title: Strategic Workforce Planning
description: Covers workforce planning for various organization types. Topics include strategic planning, scheduling, succession planning, gap analysis, budgeting for manpower, and new HR configurations like self-managed teams, telecommuting, and outsourcing.

title: Organizational Behavior and Management (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level organizational behavior. Covers communication, self-awareness, perception, motivation, problem-solving, culture, leadership theories, and organizational change.

title: Project Management (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level project management. Covers project and program management principles, roles, matrix organization, and project management techniques. Requires proposal development, case studies, and independent projects.

title: Production and Operations Management (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level operations management. Covers strategies, process design, and quantitative techniques. Uses Excel for multivariate constraints including forecasting, scheduling, inventory control, and quality control.

title: Production and Operations Management Lab (Graduate)
description: Hands-on lab for graduate operations management. Students develop mathematical models and software-based implementations for cost optimization in production planning scenarios.

title: Entrepreneurship (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level entrepreneurship. Covers evaluation, development, and creation of a successful business including organizational structure, market analysis, venture financing, and business plan development.

title: Launching Innovative Startups (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level startup course covering the entrepreneur development process from ideation through funding and marketing launch. Includes design thinking, lean startup, and market validation.

title: Agility-Based Leadership (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level agility-based leadership using Business Agility Institute best practices. Covers cultural engagement, agile principles, operational efficiency, and strategies for workforce engagement and continuous improvement.

title: Risk Management
description: Teaches risk management concepts, processes, and strategy in a corporate environment. Topics include risk nature, management structure, information gathering, data analysis tools, and risk management techniques. Requires case studies and project.

title: Agile Project Management
description: Covers scrum-based agile project management. Topics include user stories, estimation techniques, sprint management, customer collaboration, progress measurement, and the roles of Scrum Master, Product Owner, and Development Team.

title: Strategic Management & Leadership
description: Covers strategic management and leadership principles. Topics include ethics, culture and leadership, job design, decision-making, problem diagnosis, change management, and implementation. Team-based culminating consulting project.

title: Logistics and Operations Management
description: Covers logistics and operations management including production, warehousing, transportation, and service delivery. Uses quantitative analytical techniques to make logistics and operations decisions in the context of e-commerce and globalization.

title: International Business Management
description: Covers international business environment including economic, financial, political, and cultural aspects of global trade. Topics include global organizational design and international management techniques. Requires country screening analysis.

title: Management of Innovation
description: Equips students with knowledge and skills to manage new and innovative enterprises. Topics include technology forecasting, program/product selection, market development, financial management, regulations, and ethics.

title: Technology and Product Management
description: Provides practical experience in product development. Covers technology product design, planning, production, marketing, product life cycle, MRD, product positioning, channel inventory management, and outbound communications.

title: Global Outsourcing and Vendor Management
description: Covers global outsourcing management and supplier management. Topics include sourcing decisions, pricing dynamics, ethical considerations, globalization, risk management, and interaction with other organizational functions.

title: Marketing Management (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level marketing management. Studies marketing via real-world cases covering situation assessment, strategy formulation, marketing planning, implementation, and evaluation.

title: Monetizing Intellectual Property (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level IP monetization. Covers innovative models for generating capital from intangible assets including licensing, royalty securitizations, collateralization, copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets, and patents.

title: The Art of Negotiation (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level negotiation. Develops advanced skills for complex negotiation scenarios including strategy, disciplined preparation, and interpersonal skills. Includes Silicon Valley-focused case studies and simulations.

title: Strategic Marketing
description: Covers marketing research and data analysis for strategic positioning. Includes primary and secondary research techniques, market segmentation, strategic positioning, and channel marketing. Requires a marketing research project.

title: Global Marketing
description: Develops global marketing strategies including marketing research, segmentation, and positioning. Students incorporate global product policy decisions into a comprehensive market entry plan.

title: Global Trade and Operations
description: Develops knowledge and understanding of the global marketing environment, concepts, and tools for global market penetration. Covers managerial identification of opportunities, problem resolution, and implementation of solutions.

title: Consumer and Buyer Behavior
description: Applies modern behavior theory to purchasing decision-making. Topics include psychology of consumption, brand loyalty, group vs. individual decision-making, intuitive vs. rational decision-making, and integration of buyer behavior into marketing and sales strategies.

title: Sales Management
description: Covers selling strategies, sales force management, relationship and product selling, customer relationship ownership, and customer personas. Additional topics include forecasting, pricing, negotiation, recruitment, territory assignment, and channel management.

title: Brand Management and Marketing
description: Covers building, measuring, and increasing brand equity. Topics include brand strategy, branding in the digital era, naming new products, and building brand extensions.

title: Digital Marketing and Social Media
description: Covers digital marketing and social media influence using creativity, critical thinking, and data analysis. Teaches the ASCOR digital marketing framework, online value proposition optimization, and creation of multistage digital marketing campaigns.

title: Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
description: Teaches search engine algorithms and optimization techniques to achieve high rankings. Topics include keyword research, meta tag editing, web scraping, indexing concepts, and alternatives to Google. Assumes working knowledge of HTML.

title: Emotional Intelligence (Graduate)
description: Graduate-level EI course. Covers recognizing and controlling emotions in oneself and others, increasing EQ, and managing interpersonal relations. Students assess their EQ at the start and end of the course.

title: Emotional Intelligence Essentials
description: Focuses on mastery of emotional intelligence for managing interpersonal relations. First half covers recognizing EQ issues in others and oneself. Second half covers synthesizing solutions in complex professional and personal relationships.
